Benzoatithermus flavus is a species of bacterium that belongs to the phylum Firmicutes. It is a thermophilic, aerobic, and spore-forming bacterium, meaning it can survive in high-temperature environments and requires oxygen for growth, and it can form resistant spores to withstand adverse conditions.

The cells of Benzoatithermus flavus are rod-shaped and typically measure around 0.5-0.7 μm in width and 2-4 μm in length. They are Gram-positive, indicating that their cell walls contain a thick layer of peptidoglycan.

This species is known to be capable of degrading aromatic compounds, such as benzoate, and using them as a source of carbon and energy for its growth and metabolism. It can thrive in environments with moderate to high temperatures, typically between 50°C and 70°C.

Benzoatithermus flavus has been isolated from various thermal environments, such as hot springs and geothermal areas. Its ability to degrade aromatic compounds and its thermophilic nature make it a potentially interesting microorganism for applications in bioremediation and biotechnology.
